thread.title: Copper slumps to six-year low on China demand woes
thread.title_full: Copper slumps to six-year low on China demand woes - MarketWatch

author: Sara Sjolin
title: Copper slumps to six-year low on China demand woes
text:
Metals prices dropped across the board on Tuesday, with copper sliding to a more-than-six-year low on concerns over future demand from China.
High-grade copper for September delivery HGU5, -1.74% lost 3 cents, or 1.2%, to $2.29 a pound, setting it on track for its lowest settlement price since July 2009. On Monday, the industrial metal shaved off 1.3% against a backdrop of worries that China’s recent devaluation of the yuan will slow down the country’s import of copper. Like many other commodities, copper is traded in dollars, so a stronger greenback against the yuan means the metal gets more expensive for Chinese buyers.
“While speculation continues regarding the timing, rationale, and prognosis for further depreciation, macroeconomic data out of China are weak and will continue the pressure towards yuan devaluation,” analysts from Barclays said in a note on Monday.
But they reiterated their call that China’s copper consumption will increase year-over-year in 2015, based on a belief that the world’s second largest economy will stabilize in the second half of the year via stimulus measures.
“However, the deterioration in the Chinese economy may continue, and the risk of a Chinese hard landing appears to be growing, not declining, which would undermine our assumption [for copper],” they added.
In other metals trading on Tuesday, gold for December delivery GCZ5, -0.61% slipped 90 cents, or 0.1%, to $1,117.50 an ounce, pulling back after rising $5.70 on Monday .
September Silver SIU5, -3.61% also dropped on Tuesday, down 15 cents, or 1%, to $15.15 an ounce. Palladium for the same month PAU5, -2.83% shaved off $6, or 1%, to $607.80 an ounce, while October platinum PLV5, -1.32% gave up $4.60, or 0.5%, to $996.60 an ounce.
In U.S. economic news on Tuesday, traders will keep an eye out for a July reading on housing starts due at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, with economists polled by MarketWatch expecting 1.185 million starts .
